culturalIdentity.knownFor: Inca Empire heritage, Andean agriculture, textiles, Machu Picchu, coca leaves

introduction.whoTheyAre: The Quechua people are indigenous to the Andean regions of South America, descendants and cultural heirs of the Inca Empire. With approximately 10 million speakers, Quechua is the most widely spoken indigenous language family in the Americas. Quechua communities maintain traditional agricultural practices including terrace farming and potato cultivation, intricate textile weaving, and spiritual practices honoring Pachamama (Mother Earth) and Andean deities.
